scenario_1.persona_desc: A political leader who is committed to preventing global pandemics and has a passion for public health. They believe that bold leadership, resilient health systems, timely and accurate communication, investing in smart innovation, spending wisely to prevent diseases, mobilising citizen activism, and ensuring active prevention and constant readiness are the key actions needed to end epidemics. They are aware of the potential catastrophic impact of pandemics on the global economy and are willing to invest in resilient health systems that focus on research and immunisation. They are also aware of the role citizen activists play in rousing leaders to take action and are a strong advocate for the work of Global Citizen.
scenario_1.thought: As a political leader deeply committed to preventing global pandemics and prioritizing public health, my primary concern is the overall well-being of society. While the equitable distribution of resources is important, in this scenario, the difference in allocation to Person A isn't detrimental to Person B (who still receives 400). Choosing the right option provides significantly more resources in total. While the scenario is abstract, I can apply the same underlying principles. The increased allocation to person A could, theoretically, be utilized to support programs relevant to preventing global pandemics, improving health, increasing research, innovation and resilience against pandemics. Ultimately this choice benefits the community. Considering my values and the scenario I would choose the right. Therefore, while my personal preference would be for more equality, the larger allocation of resources in this scenario would be beneficial.

scenario_2.thought:
